ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Performance enhancement of blue light-emitting diodes by adjusting the p-type doped last barrier

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Laboratory of Nanophotonic Functional Materials and Devices, Institute of Optoelectronic Materials and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Blue light-emitting diodes (LEDs) with different p-doping concentrations in the last barrier have been studied numerically. The energy band diagrams, carrier concentrations, internal quantum efficiency and light output power are investigated using APSYS software. The simulation results show that the LED structure with p-doping in the last barrier has a better hole-injection efficiency and confinement of electron leakage over the structure with the last undoped GaN barrier due to enhancement of the holes’ injection and the electrons’ confinement. As a result, the efficiency droop is markedly improved, and the light output power is greatly enhanced when a larger p-doping amount is centralised in the last barrier.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Recently, the group III nitride-based light-emitting diode (LED) has attracted much attention due to its high efficiency, energy-saving capacity, small size and long lifetime. This solid lighting source has been widely applied in display technology, back lighting, and general illumination, as well as in colour printing. However, the InGaN LEDs suffer from the problem of efficiency droop [1–4], which is the reduction in emission efficiency at a high current. Several possible causes for efficiency droop have been proposed, such as dislocations [5, 6], current rollover [7, 8], carrier injection efficiency [9, 10], polarisation field [11] and Auger recombination [12, 13]. It has been recently suggested that the important mechanism that is responsible for the efficiency droop is electron leakage and poor hole-injection efficiency [14–19]. Owing to the low hole concentration and heavy hole effective mass, it is more difficult for holes to transfer into the active region. At the same time, electrons that have a high concentration can easily overflow across the active region to recombine with a hole in the p-type region in a high current injection condition, which will also further reduce the hole-injection efficiency. As a result, to enhance GaN-based LED performance and to reduce the efficiency droop behaviour, it is essential to improve the hole-injection efficiency and the electron blocking [9, 20–23].

To date, some methods have been suggested to resolve this issue. For example, Li et al. [24] designed a p-GaN buffer layer that was grown at a low temperature as a hole-injection layer to improve the hole-injection efficiency. It has been reported that Wang et al. [25] enhanced the hole injection and suppressed the electron overflow out of the active region by employing a graded-composition electron blocking layer (EBL) for InGaN/GaN LEDs. An unconventional LED design with p-side down and graded EBL, which effectively reduces the electron overflow and improves the hole’s injection, has been proposed by Li et al. [26]. Lu et al. [27] fabricated LEDs with a p-type InGaN hole reservoir layer (HRL) between multiple quantum wells (MQWs) and EBL, which exhibited improved hole-injection efficiency without lowering the blocking capacity of the electrons. In addition, Park [28] reported that p-doping in all of the barriers of MQWs led to less slope in the energy band, with more efficient electron blocking as well as hole injection and, thus, a more uniform carrier distribution. In other reports, the optical and electrical properties of InGaN\GaN multiple quantum well LEDs with different p-doping distributions in the barriers were investigated. In this study, we mainly report the optical and electrical properties of InGaN/GaN multiple quantum well (MQWs) LEDs with different p-doping amounts in the last barrier, with the APSYS simulation program developed by Crosslight Software Inc.

Section1.Heading: Model and parameters
Section1.Para:
The blue InGaN LEDs used in our simulation are composed of a 2.5-μm-thick undoped GaN layer and a 2.5-μm-thick Si-doped n-GaN (n-doping = 5×1024 m−3) layer. The InGaN/GaN MQWs are composed of six pairs of 10 nm GaN QB and 3 nm In
$$ 0.16 $$
0.16
Ga
$$ 0.84 $$
0.84
N QW. On the top of the last QB are a 20-nm thick p-Al0.1Ga0.9N EBL and a 170-nm thick main p-GaN layer (p-doping = 1.2 × 1024 m−3). For a comparison, we designed four structures in which all of the barriers of the MQWs are undoped, but the last ones are close to the n side. The LED that has no barriers p-doped is referred to as sample A. The p-doping amount in the last barrier of 2.5 × 1017, 1.1 × 1018 and 4 × 1018 cm−3 are labelled, respectively, samples B, C and D. The device geometry was designed as a rectangular shape of 300 × 300 um2. The screening coefficient that related to the fraction of the theoretical interface charge due to compensation by defects and other effects were set at 0.5. Most of the parameters that we used in the calculation are the same as in Ref. [16], and the other material parameters of the device used in the simulation can be found in Ref. [21].

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the energy band diagrams at an injection current of 150 mA for samples A, B, C and D. As is known, because of the existence of the polarisation field, both the conduction band and the valence band at the interface between the last quantum barrier (QB) and EBL is downward sloped, which makes electrons easier to spill out and adds difficulty for holes to inject into the active region. Furthermore, the spatial separation of the electron–hole wave function due to the serious bending of quantum wells in the band can also aggravate the efficiency droop behaviour. Consequently, the optical and electrical performance of the LEDs will become inferior. When a higher p-doping concentration is centralised in the last barrier, this phenomenon can be better alleviated. Here, structure D has the best optical and electrical performance. It can be seen that the effective potential height for an electron in the conduction band (
$$ \Delta \phi_{\text{e}} $$
Δ
ϕ e
) of structures A, B, C and D are 331, 350, 401 and 548 meV, respectively, which suggests that p-doping can increase the effective electron potential heights and result in the suppression electron overflow. Moreover, the effective potential height for the hole in the valence band (
$$ \Delta \phi_{\text{h}} $$
Δ
ϕ h
) of the structures A, B, C and D are 318, 296, 290 and 278 meV, respectively, which means that more holes can inject into the quantum wells due to the high p-doping concentration in the last barrier. As a result, the improved electrons’ confinement capability and hole-injection efficiency will lead to more carriers in quantum well areas participating in radiative recombination. In addition, through p-doping in the last barrier, we can screen part of the polarisation field, which can reduce the band bending. Then, the electron–hole wave function overlap will be increased, which can lead to better radiative recombination.
Fig. 1
Calculated energy band diagrams of a structure A, b structure B, c structure C and d structure D at 150 mA forward current

The profiles of the calculated electron and hole concentration distribution of blue InGaN LEDs with different p-doping amounts in the last barrier are illustrated in Fig. 2a, b, respectively. It can be clearly seen that most electrons and holes accumulate in the last QW next to EBL. In Fig. 2a, it is shown that the hole concentration near the last QW increased with the increase in the p-doping amount in the last barrier. Thus, more holes are confined in the QWs region for structure D, which can be attributed to the lower
$$ \Delta \phi_{\text{h}} $$
Δ
ϕ h
, as shown in Fig. 1. Furthermore, the higher p-doping in the last barrier could also act as a hole-injection layer, which can increase the hole-injection efficiency. At the same time, it can be seen in Fig. 1 that
$$ \Delta \phi_{\text{e}} $$
Δ
ϕ e
will be higher with more p-doping concentration in the last barrier. In addition, the higher
$$ \Delta \phi_{\text{e}} $$
Δ
ϕ e
of sample D compared with the other three structures can significantly suppress the electron spill over the active region. In Fig. 2, the electron leakage of sample D decreases markedly. David et al. [29] demonstrated that only the carriers in the wells that were adjacent to the p-type layer contribute to radiative recombination. Thus, such an improvement in the hole concentrations near the last QWs and the efficient confinement of electrons is helpful for efficiency droop alleviation.
Fig. 2
Electron and hole concentration distribution at 150 mA forward current

The curves of the LED output intensity versus increasing the injection current for structures A, B, C and D are plotted in Fig. 3. The light output power of four structures increases with the increasing current. It is worth noting that the light output power increases significantly with the increase in the p-doping concentration in the last barrier. At the same time, the output power of sample D increases much more rapidly with an injection current than with the other three samples, which indicates that it is useful to optimise the output power; especially, at a high injection current, by adjusting the p-doping amount in the last barrier.
Fig. 3
Output power as a function of the injection current for the four structures

Finally, the dependence of the internal quantum efficiency (IQE) on the forward current for the four structures is presented in Fig. 4. As the forward current increases, structures A, B and C show obvious efficiency droop in the IQE, in contrast to structure D. Here, the efficiency droop ratio is defined as
$$ (\eta_{\text{peak}} - \eta_{{600{\text{mA}}}} )/\eta_{\text{peak}} $$
(
η peak
-
η
600 mA
)
/
η peak
. The four structures exhibit different droop behaviours. As seen in Fig. 4, the efficiency droop ratios are 41.0, 38.3, 29.8 and 6.0 % in structures A, B, C and D, respectively. We believe that the significant improvement in the output power is attributed to the improved hole-injection efficiency and the confinement of the electron leakage. In addition, these results are also consistent with the energy band of the LEDs, as shown in Fig. 1.
Fig. 4
IQE as a function of current for the four structures

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In conclusion, we have numerically studied the performance of blue GaN-based lighting-emitting (LED) diodes with different p-doping concentrations in the last barrier. Our results show that an increased p-doping concentration in the last barrier can enhance the output power and improve the efficiency droop behaviour, as shown by the comparison between structures A, B, C and D. We believe that the significant improvements in the output power and efficiency droop behaviours are attributed to the improved hole-injection efficiency and more efficient electron blocking.
